bibl.title: The Enigma of Kab Marfu'a: Precious Gems in Egypt's Eastern Desert.
bibl.note: Survey conducted by the Berenike Project of the University of Delaware and Leiden University / University of California at Los Angeles in Kab Marfu'a (about 65 km south-west of Marsa Alam), which probably was a beryl-working and trading community. More than 100 structures spread out over an area of about 250 x 300 m, pottery sherds from the 1st to the 5th century AD.
bibl.seg: SIDEBOTHAM Steven E., Hans BARNARD, Lisa A. PINTOZZI, and Roberta S. TOMBER, The Enigma of Kab Marfu'a: Precious Gems in Egypt's Eastern Desert.
Minerva 16 (2005) No. 1, pp. 24-26, 8 figg. n./bl. et coul.

Survey conducted by the Berenike Project of the University of Delaware and Leiden University / University of California at Los Angeles in Kab Marfu'a (about 65 km south-west of Marsa Alam), which probably was a beryl-working and trading community. More than 100 structures spread out over an area of about 250 x 300 m, pottery sherds from the 1st to the 5th century AD.
